docs.lead_paragraph: For the first time since the 19th century, when New York was a far different, far smaller place, fewer than 60,000 people died in the five boroughs in 2002, continuing a steady decline that began in the early 1990's and setting a record low for the city's death rate. Infant mortality, too, reached a record low -- less than half the rate of the 1980's. AIDS persisted as a leading killer of black and Hispanic New Yorkers -- but less so in Queens. People in Manhattan were more likely than those in the other boroughs to take their own lives, but less likely to die of diabetes. New Yorkers were more likely than ever to die in nursing homes, and less likely to die at home. Men were more likely than women to be run over while crossing the street, and elderly pedestrians were much more likely to be killed than younger ones.

headline.main: New Yorkers Can't Beat Death, But Data Says They're Gaining

docs.abstract: Summary of Vital Statistics reports that 59,651 people died in New York City in 2002, continuing steady decline that began in early 1990's and setting record low for city's death rate; infant mortality reached record low of 6 deaths per 1,000 babies--less than half rate of 1980's; AIDS deaths and homicides, which together claimed 2,300 lives in 2002, were down from over 8,000 in some years in 1990's; 122,937 babies were born in city in 2002, lowest birth rate since 'baby bust' of 1970's and early 1980's; graph (M)

docs.section_name: Front Page; Health; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: For Joy Persaud, 49, of East New York, Brooklyn, the trouble starts when she hears a noise in her head. In those moments, no matter where she is, she sits on the floor, arms crossed, and waits for a seizure. Ms. Persaud has epilepsy, and three to five times a week the seizures come. Though this has been her life for five years, she remains fearless and upbeat. In the summertime, she has cookouts every week for her neighbors. ''I like things done to me in the proper way and I do it back,'' Ms. Persaud said. ''And because of that I think the blessings come to me.''

headline.main: The Neediest Cases; Recounting the Blessings of Life as Well as Its Battles

docs.abstract: Nia-Malika Henderson The Neediest Cases column discusses difficulties experienced by Joy Persaud, who is trying to raise her children while battling epilepsy; photo (M)

keywords.value: NEW YORK TIMES NEEDIEST CASES FUND

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Gertie F. Marx, a New York anesthesiologist who helped advance the use of modern epidural injections that ease women's pain during childbirth, died on Sunday at the Schervier Nursing Care Center in the Bronx, according to Dr. Jill M. Rabin, a friend and colleague. Dr. Marx was 91. At a time when anesthesia was reserved for complicated deliveries and Caesarean sections, Dr. Marx became an early and vigorous advocate of what became known as the epidural and helped show that it was safe and effective. The procedure places a catheter next to a patient's spine, allowing a sedative to block the sensation of pain without paralyzing the birth canal.

headline.main: Dr. Gertie F. Marx, 91, A Pioneer in Her Specialty
